job_title: Enquiry Officer in Daresbury, England
pros:
Team managers are very friendly, by and large, the company also puts on a lot of events which are completely free to employees (mostly).   It also has quite a forgiving sickness policy and is very accommodating for maternity leave etc.

There is a bonus - achievable only if you are superhuman.

decent amount of holidays too - although bank holidays are taken from your overall allocation

overtime is regularly offered, a good option for those who can commit to an extra hour or two
cons:
it was said in the interview your time is usually split 50/50 between being on the phones and being on back office (answering emails etc), this is completely untrue. There are not enough Enquiry Officers and you will find yourself on the phones about 70% of the time.

If you find yourself on the phone to someone demanding to speak to a manager, even if they have a viable reason to do so, you will be hard pressed to find a manager that will actually take over that call.

Pay for Enquiry Officers is very low. Laughably the management will have the cheek to say 'it's better than other call centres' - as if being slightly above average is something to be proud of...  This is a complete false economy. An EO has no incentive to stay with such little pay/benefits and this is reflected in the high rate of attrition for this particular role. 

There is almost no opportunity for progression, 'internal' opportunities will crop up every now and again but this is a facade. The position will soon be opened up externally and rather than taking advantage of the resources they already have they would rather take an external applicant... either that or they will offer the position on a seconded basis because they are so unwilling to commit to giving you the position permanently.

changes are often implemented without warning or at least very little warning. They also seem to be made in a completely reactionary manner, almost as if they are being made by execs who have never actually worked on the phones...

Too much red tape.

review_title: If you want to progress or be invested in stay away....
job_title: Enquiry Officer in Warrington, North West England, England
pros: You know how they say when you join the army you meet your second family and friends for life? Same thing at this place. The management, business strategy, facilities and lack of care from anyone other than the people on your team helps forge many bonds of friendship.... Oh and the canteen does some half decent food.
cons:
Current staff are being leaned on to give good reviews to make the place seem better for prospective employees. Managers are not present. They do not invest in their staff. They lie and ignore and put off responding in the hopes that you will go away. They might be nice to your face but will comment and talk about you behind your back, and they will recognise others/take recognition for your hard work. The expectations on staff performance are too high considering the lack of resources, working tools or support that is actually given. In the space of 6 months they must of gone through 3 maybe 4 heads of operation (the same post). The CEO has his head in the sand and keeps telling everyone it will be better in the long run. Bare with us we are sorting it. But actually nothing gets done for months or if it does it isn’t communicated. Nobody knows what’s going on, nobody is given any real opportunity to progress or share their ideas to help improve the workplace. The office is in the sticks (a good 10 minute drive from the nearest shop).  You are lied to when applying about the amount of time you will spend off the phones (they say 50/50 it’s more 95% of the time
Online 5% offline during which you have to complete your own review documents, coaching logs and normal work.) no time is given for development and learning - unless it’s for your current role and is a sporadic 6 monthly 3 hour upskill session that doesn’t really manage to upskill anything other than your sleep levels. OS is trying to give a facelift to an old tired company facade and it just isn’t happening. Also as much as they try to tell you they’re not it’s an “if the face fits” culture through and through. Couldn’t make a decent internal management decision with a clear rationale explanation and positive outcome if it was mapped out for them step by step (having attempted to actually do this and watch them mess it up I speak from experience). In my last 2 months I don’t think there was a single person in the business who actually wanted to be there. The whole atmosphere and culture is negative, blood sucking and damaging to mental health (of which you’ll receive no support with if you have any mental health issues). I could go on and on waxing lyrical but I guess I’ve put enough for you to get the picture. STAY AWAY.

review_title: Not a pleasant place to work
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Koramangala
pros:
Canteen is nice; the food is delicious 

Christmas party was fun

Benefits were ok in terms of pension etc
cons:
There is an air of mistrust between management and lower level employees. This is pervasive through the whole company, there are policies and rules in place that are all about bullying people into submission rather than encouraging an environment of personal responsibility.

I was not an EO, but did empathise with their struggles. It’s essentiallh a dead end job that very few people get out of, EO’s are rarely given the chance to progress into other areas of the business and are treated like they are replaceable.

Upper management/ corporate/executive office will often ask for employees opinions and then ignore them. I distinctly remember one of the directors running a competition to name the canteen, everyone could submit an answer and if theirs was picked they would get a prize. There were hundreds of suggestions and the director decided instead that he wanted to name it after a monty python sketch. Literally proving anyone outside the inner circle has no voice.

I generally found the atmosphere extremely negative. Employees are not positively reinforced, there’s no reward or praise for a job well done, just accusations, stress, targets, lots of unhappy faces for the 90% that are keeping the company running. 

Very different rules for people in different areas of the business. 

I would say it’s useless if your looking for a career across all areas of the business. I saw EOs stuck and unappreciated, IOs stressed and over worked with again no opportunities to move up to. Even some of the other teams who don’t appear to do much work and get an easy ride will find themselves unqualified when it comes time to move on. I saw this because I saw several people plucked from other corporate teams, moved around, put in jobs they weren’t qualified before simply because they were a favourite of a director. I’ve seen more than one of them leave and their LinkedIn now shows they are in a more junior position than they held at OS.

CEO comes across as self obsessed, vain and narcissistic which is shocking considering he doesn’t even write his own speeches.

review_title: You couldn't pay me to work here again.
job_title: Investigator in Daresbury, England
pros:
The people - my team were amazing and my main motivation to keep coming in.  
The canteen -  the range and price of the food was pretty high in comparison to other places I've worked.
cons:
I honestly don't know where to begin.

- Working as an Investigator at OS means dealing with the stress and pressure of a high flying job (doctor, solicitor etc) but receiving none of the prestige or money. The salary OS offers is woefully low in comparison to similar roles. 

- Last year we were told we would not receive bonuses or an annual pay review and that some staff could expect to be made redundant.   Prior to these announcements  the company blew their budget on widescreen TVs that no one watches, a learning tool that no one uses,  a new case management system that doesn't work and randomly: a chandelier. This doesn't even begin to cover the ineptitude and lack of foresight that can be found at OS. 

- A sizeable portion of the management team appear to have joined a cult where they've been brainwashed into believing OS is a great place to work (I believe some of them have left positive reviews on this site,  it's the only explanation)  and  that they don't value quantity over quality when it comes to casework.  They parrot generic claptrap at anyone who raises an issue with the changes they're implementing and anyone who expresses concern is treated to wilful obtuseness  and/or is accused of not "embracing change."

- Shortly before I left,  they increased the targets and used the new CMS (which remember, doesn't actually work that well) as the justification for this when in actual fact it's because they need to generate more revenue to dig themselves out of the hole they've gotten themselves into. 

- The only positive aspect of working at OS was the flexi time, which allowed us to split our time between the office and working from home as we saw fit.  This was arbitrarily changed,  so that now anyone wanting to work in this way must gain prior approval (please sir, I want some more!!) and it was made very clear that these requests were to be made sparingly. When this was challenged,  we were told it was in an effort to get away from "legacy thinking" and we were receiving high missed calls on Fridays due to staff leaving early. This was barely a week after we'd been told that the majority of our contact from customers is online. 

- Another small saving grace was the option to have breakfast in the canteen of a morning, as they serve a decent fry up.  However, shortly before I left,  the canteen began serving breakfast on paper plates and small plastic cutlery, which made eating fairly awkward.  When we asked why this was happening,  the canteen staff told us that management had requested this,  in an effort to dissuade people from having breakfast.  Not only does this suck for the environment but this is such a petty and cynical move. If I hadn't already been leaving,  this would have pushed me over the edge.   

The bottom line is that OS is actively creating a hostile working environment, paying its staff a pittance,  disregarding the views of its staff and offering its staff no opportunities for growth/progression. I honestly am so disappointed with how far this place has fallen. We were promised all manner of things at interview and virtually  none have come to fruition.  I don't see the sense in upsetting your workforce on multiple occasions than requesting more work from them,  but if you do: you should apply to work here. My advice to the remaining staff: do not drink the kool-aid, get out whilst you can!
